content.body: Ah right, and I still can't repro it on demand either :/
https://beta.w3.org/ vs. https://whatwg.org/ ... hmm... what if we made our corners... more rounded...

Looking at https://github.com/validator/validator/issues/1249, I am wondering, should an element that’s not keyboard-focusable be allowed to have an `alt` attribute?

Specifically, at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/image-maps.html#the-area-element:attr-area-alt-4 the spec says:
> If the `area` element has no `href` attribute, then the area represented by the element cannot be selected, and the `alt` attribute must be omitted.

But the fact that Scott posted a markup snippet with an `href`-less `area` element that has an `alt` attribute makes me think that `alt` content can still get exposed usefully to AT somehow?

If the area element has no href attribute, then the area represented by the element cannot be selected, and the alt attribute must be omitted.

But the fact that Scott posted a markup snippet with an href-less area element that has an alt attribute makes me think that alt content can still get exposed usefully to AT somehow?

content.body: Just a very simple UNO IDL example:
balazs: what are you trying to accomplish? Sounds like Uno and WebIDL are formats with different purposes
content.formatted_body: balazs: what are you trying to accomplish? Sounds like Uno and WebIDL are formats with different purposes

content.body:
Noam Rosenthal: thanks for the response. :) I am trying to connect C++ and javascript with WebIDL Binder for WebAssembly. And I am following the steps for that on the emscipten site: https://emscripten.org/docs/porting/connecting_cpp_and_javascript/WebIDL-Binder.html
https://emscripten.org/docs/porting/connecting_cpp_and_javascript/WebIDL-Binder.html#a-quick-example

content.body: Yea one is for binding web-exposed scripts to C++ implementation and I guess the other one is for OpenOffice? I guess you *might* be able to reuse some parser code but I wouldn't try to match semantics
content.formatted_body: Yea one is for binding web-exposed scripts to C++ implementation and I guess the other one is for OpenOffice? I guess you might be able to reuse some parser code but I wouldn't try to match semantics

content.body:
> <@noamr:matrix.org> Yea one is for binding web-exposed scripts to C++ implementation and I guess the other one is for OpenOffice? I guess you *might* be able to reuse some parser code but I wouldn't try to match semantics

Yes the other one is for LibreOffice. (the older one was the OpenOffice, it was forked.) :)
